title: Equifax Data Breach (2017)
description: Equifax’s consumer-credit web portal was meant to let users dispute credit-report errors. A forgotten, vulnerable Struts component and missing patching process left the portal open to remote-code execution, exposing ~148 million consumer records.
objectives:
1. Timely patch management for all third-party frameworks (< 72 h SLA after CVE release).
2. Hardened configuration & least privilege on all internet-facing portals.
3. Continuous vulnerability scanning to verify that patches and config controls remain in place.
test_plan:
Weekly authenticated vulnerability scan (N-map + OpenVAS).
Quarterly external pen-test targeting public portals.
Verify CVE-2017-5638 exploit blocked after every build via unit test harness.
defect_management: All security findings logged in Jira with “SEC-” key, severity S0–S4, 24-h SLA for S0/S1. Fix linked to commit and re-tested before closure.
reviews:
Monthly patch-status audit against NVD list.
Quarterly SQA review of compliance with OWASP and IEEE 730 process clauses.
Findings reported at CISO staff meeting.
supplier_control: All third-party components tracked in SBOM; suppliers must issue patch notices within 24 h and provide SHA-256 hashes for integrity checks.
references:
United States Government Accountability Office. (2018). DATA PROTECTION actions taken by Equifax and federal agencies in response to the 2017 breach. In GAO-18-559. https://www.gao.gov/assets/gao-18-559.pdf

OWASP. (2021). A05 Security Misconfiguration - OWASP Top 10:2021. https://owasp.org/Top10/A05_2021-Security_Misconfiguration/

IEEE 730-2014 Standard for Software Quality Assurance Processes. (2014). https://standards.ieee.org/ieee/730/5284/
purpose: Prevent recurrence of large-scale data breaches by closing patch-management gaps, enforcing secure configuration, and validating fixes through continuous security testing.
